FoodToEat: Probiotics like yogurt, garlic (natural antifungal), coconut oil, and foods rich in Omega-3s (e.g., salmon, nuts) can help balance yeast levels. Additionally, ginger, turmeric, and cinnamon have antifungal properties. Lemon and lime juice can also aid digestion and balance pH levels.
FoodToAvoid: High-sugar foods, refined carbs, alcohol, and fermented foods, as they can feed fungal overgrowth like Candida​

FoodToEat: Anti-inflammatory foods such as fatty fish (rich in Omega-3), flaxseeds, and turmeric can reduce inflammation linked to allergic reactions. Probiotic-rich foods (e.g., yogurt, kefir) might help boost gut health and immune response.
FoodToAvoid: Common allergens (e.g., dairy, gluten, soy, nuts), processed foods, and sugar may aggravate symptoms

FoodToEat: Bananas, melons, oatmeal, and whole grains are gentle on the stomach. Vegetables like broccoli, asparagus, and leafy greens are good options. Ginger can soothe the digestive tract.
FoodToAvoid: Acidic foods (e.g., tomatoes, citrus), chocolate, spicy foods, coffee, and alcohol can trigger acid reflux​

FoodToEat: Fiber-rich foods (e.g., fruits, vegetables, whole grains), and healthy fats (e.g., olive oil, avocados). Vitamin D and calcium-rich foods are essential for those with liver conditions affecting bile flow.
FoodToAvoid: Saturated fats, fried foods, and high-cholesterol foods should be minimized to reduce liver stress​

FoodToEat: A balanced diet with a focus on antioxidants (berries, leafy greens), whole grains, and lean proteins can support immune recovery. Probiotics help restore gut health if antibiotics were involved.
FoodToAvoid: Highly processed foods, sugar, and alcohol, which can further irritate the body during recovery​

FoodToEat: Lean proteins, low-fat dairy, and fibrous foods (e.g., apples, carrots, oatmeal). Probiotics like yogurt can help balance stomach flora.
FoodToAvoid: Spicy foods, alcohol, caffeine, and acidic foods like citrus and tomatoes​

FoodToEat: High-protein foods (e.g., lean meats, eggs), whole grains, and fruits and vegetables rich in antioxidants. Probiotic-rich foods like yogurt can help support gut health.
FoodToAvoid: Raw or undercooked foods that may carry bacteria, and foods high in sugar which may compromise immune function

FoodToEat: Whole grains, legumes, leafy greens, and healthy fats (e.g., olive oil, nuts). Foods with a low glycemic index like berries, sweet potatoes, and quinoa can help regulate blood sugar levels.
FoodToAvoid: Sugary foods, refined carbohydrates, and processed snacks should be minimized to maintain balanced blood sugar

FoodToEat: Bland foods like bananas, rice, applesauce, and toast (BRAT diet). Hydration is key, so soups and electrolyte-rich drinks (e.g., coconut water) are recommended.
FoodToAvoid: Dairy, caffeine, fatty foods, and highly seasoned foods, which may irritate the stomach

FoodToEat: Omega-3 rich foods (like salmon, flaxseeds), antioxidant-rich fruits (berries, apples), and vegetables may reduce inflammation and improve lung function. Ginger and turmeric can help reduce symptoms.
FoodToAvoid: Processed foods, sulfite-containing foods (like dried fruits, wine), and dairy for some people as they may trigger symptoms.

FoodToEat: The DASH diet is highly recommended for managing blood pressure. It includes fruits, vegetables (especially potassium-rich like bananas, leafy greens), whole grains, and lean proteins (like poultry, fish). Foods rich in magnesium like oats and nuts are also beneficial.
FoodToAvoid: Limit high-sodium foods like processed snacks, canned goods, and salty condiments. Also, minimize alcohol intake

FoodToEat: Magnesium-rich foods (like spinach, almonds), riboflavin (found in eggs, milk), and Coenzyme Q10 sources (like meats, oily fish) are helpful for prevention.
FoodToAvoid: Caffeine, alcohol (especially red wine), aged cheeses, and processed meats can trigger migraines in sensitive individuals

FoodToEat: Anti-inflammatory foods such as fatty fish (salmon, mackerel), nuts, seeds, and green leafy vegetables can reduce joint inflammation and pain.
FoodToAvoid: Limit inflammatory foods like processed sugars, trans fats, and refined carbs.

FoodToEat: Soft, nutrient-dense foods high in antioxidants (like berries), and omega-3 rich foods may aid in recovery and improve brain health.
FoodToAvoid: Limit salt, processed fats, and sugary foods that may impair cardiovascular health.

FoodToEat: Fresh fruits (like papaya, mango) and vegetables (beetroot, spinach), as well as whole grains and herbal teas, support liver function.
FoodToAvoid: Avoid fried foods, fatty meats, and alcohol, as they burden the liver.

FoodToEat: High-protein foods like eggs, chicken, and legumes help rebuild muscle and strength. Citrus fruits like oranges and lemons boost immunity.
FoodToAvoid: Limit high-fat foods and processed items, which can tax the immune system.

FoodToEat: Soft, soothing foods like oatmeal, soups, and smoothies help when mouth sores are present. Foods rich in vitamins C and A (like oranges and carrots) promote healing.
FoodToAvoid: Avoid spicy, salty, and acidic foods that can irritate blisters in the mouth.

FoodToEat: Hydrating foods and liquids like coconut water, papaya leaf juice (to boost platelet count), and vitamin C-rich fruits can aid recovery.
FoodToAvoid: Spicy, oily, and processed foods should be avoided to prevent digestive stress.

FoodToEat: Soft, easily digestible foods such as boiled potatoes, bananas, and porridge. Staying hydrated is critical, so include soups and fruit juices.
FoodToAvoid: Avoid high-fiber, greasy, and spicy foods that strain digestion during recovery.

FoodToEat: WHO recommends a nutrient-rich diet to prevent and manage undernutrition, which is common in tuberculosis patients. Key foods include protein-rich items like eggs, legumes, and meat, alongside vitamins A, C, and D-rich foods such as carrots, citrus fruits, and dairy. Fortified foods can also be beneficial
FoodToAvoid: Alcohol, High-sugar foods, Processed foods and Saturated and Trans fats.

FoodToEat: A diet rich in vitamin C (citrus fruits, berries) and zinc (nuts, seeds, and legumes) can help support immune function. Warm fluids, like soups and teas, help alleviate symptoms​
FoodToAvoid: Dairy, Sugary foods and Caffeinated drinks.

FoodToEat: Protein-rich foods such as chicken, beans, and eggs help repair body tissues. Staying hydrated with warm fluids and eating fruits high in antioxidants (like berries) supports immune health​.
FoodToAvoid: Avoid excess sugar, alcohol, and processed foods high in sodium to maintain a strong immune system.

FoodToEat: A fiber-rich diet is essential to prevent constipation, which exacerbates piles. Foods such as whole grains, fruits, and vegetables, especially those rich in water content (e.g., cucumbers, melons), are recommended. Avoid spicy and processed foods that may irritate the digestive tract.
FoodToAvoid: White bread, processed grains, and pastries can contribute to constipation, worsening piles, Spicyfoods, Alcohol and Caffeinated beverages.

FoodToAvoid: Saturated fats (like red meat, butter), trans fats (found in processed snacks), high-sodium foods, and sugary drinks, which increase the risk of heart disease​

FoodToEat: High-fiber foods (e.g., fruits, vegetables, chia seeds), and anti-inflammatory foods like berries, avocados, and ginger. These support vein health and circulation​
FoodToAvoid: Salt, sugar, and refined carbs. These can increase bloating and worsen varicose veins​

FoodToEat: Iodine-rich foods (like seaweed, fish), selenium (brazil nuts, eggs), and zinc (pumpkin seeds, legumes).
FoodToAvoid: Highly processed foods, cruciferous vegetables (like broccoli in excess), and soy products, which can interfere with thyroid hormone production​.

FoodToEat: Cruciferous vegetables (like broccoli and cauliflower), dairy, and foods high in calcium to combat bone loss.
FoodToAvoid: Iodine-rich foods (like seaweed and iodized salt) and caffeine, which can exacerbate symptoms like restlessness.
